awd_titl_txt: CIVIC-PG Track B: Catalyzing Walkable, Sustainable, and Equitable Urban Development using Innovative Transportation Strategies
awd_abstract_narration:
This Civic Innovation Challenge (CIVIC) project aims to establish innovative approaches for converting auto-oriented suburban commercial corridors into walkable, accessible, sustainable, and affordable mixed-use “activity centers” by leveraging cutting edge transportation design innovations and strong university and community partnerships. This project relies on state-of-the-art “Placemaking Alternative Intersection” strategies that have great potential to catalyze walkable development along decaying multilane suburban highways. Other benefits will include multi-modal accessibility, reduced delay, improved safety, reduced carbon footprint, improved equity, reduced per-capita cost of infrastructure, and strong economic vitality. Civic partners involve the North Carolina Department of Transportation (NCDOT), the City of Greenville, and the Town of Smithfield. The non-profit, Strong Towns, will also collaborate and ensure project results and associated tools and methods for national implementation will be widely discovered. The project provides a process for empowering community officials and NCDOT with tools and strategies for advancing sustainable, accessible, multimodal development through participatory approaches. Tools and process include 3D visualizations and development of community-specific design guidelines for implementing mixed-use development and innovative intersection models.

In this planning effort, the project team of university researchers and community organizations will work together to address research questions necessary to prepare design guidelines for the study areas. This includes gathering baseline information on land uses, density, transportation mobility, travel time, current experiences and perceptions, and other factors. Results of this Stage I effort will include the initial research agenda and assessment identifying community-specific strengths, needs, challenges related to transportation, walkability, equitable access to amenities, and economic development opportunities for a Stage 2 project. The project team and partners will devise a 12-month strategy involving community surveys, focus groups, and workshops to increase acceptance of new ideas, 3D renderings to demonstrate design strategies, and further performance analysis. Webinars and new webapps are also planned for Stage 2 to broaden the impact and vet these strategies thoroughly before a larger audience of stakeholders so that urban revitalization strategies centered around transportation can be easily applied in community plans and NCDOT planning processes. The goal is to demonstrate how to overcome obstacles to sustainable, walkable, and equitable urban design by using innovative placemaking strategies in suburban communities currently struggling with revitalization. By vetting the project vision with key stakeholders, the project will also determine the cost to implement strategies and how much can be constructed from development-financed value-capture strategies. This will help communities more likely to adopt placemaking and alternative intersection strategies and amenities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Communities across the U.S. are seeking ways to revitalize their deteriorating auto-oriented suburban commercial areas into walkable mixed-use destinations. This project shows how “Placemaking Alternative Intersections” (PAIs), along with integrated urban design and focused stakeholder partnerships for implementation, can advance holistic initiatives for better quality-of-life and sustained economic development.

America’s commercial areas function at the mercy of arterial roadways, many of which are state or U.S. highways. Principal arterials commonly have five to seven lanes resulting in a cross-section width at intersections often up to 150 feet – half the length of a football field. Such arterials are designed to carry traffic ranging from 30,000 to over 60,000 vehicles per day. Engineers struggle with how to manage such high volumes of traffic, and at the same time create conditions that can help or inhibit communities achieve their walkable development and alternative mode goals. 

There are three Alternative Intersection design families with significant potential for creating win-win outcomes in environments currently perceived to have irreconcilable conflicts between vehicular needs and people-oriented activity. For vehicles, Quadrant Intersections, U-Turn Intersections, and One-Way Split Intersections offer efficiency and safety gains. For community development, they offer a “bone structure” on which a walkable mix of uses can attach to more easily than with today’s auto-oriented paradigm. If well designed, the result could offer an ideal bridge between vehicular needs and community needs. Without such a bridge, the result could easily be lose-lose: vehicles remain in excessive congestion, while short-term relief efforts fuel longer-term induced demand. All the while adjacent uses continue to languish because walkable uses cannot take hold in an auto-oriented environment.

This project demonstrated how the design of arterials and local networks influences land use utilizing the innovative intersection and transportation design strategies that can be adopted by growing suburban communities who are increasingly confronted with auto-oriented, suburban commercial highways. It explored strategies that can catalyze the creation of walkable mixed-use activity centers, while it aimed to build an understanding about the perspectives of stakeholders with diverse expertise and backgrounds. 

During Stage 1 NSF Grant period, the project team particularly worked on establishing partnerships and understanding the worries that the key stakeholders have regarding the realization of sustainable and walkable development in general and PAI design strategies in particular.

The operational performance of the proposed Alternative Intersection design strategies was also assessed through microscopic simulation modeling. This phase of the work particularly focused on the analysis and modeling framework, describing the key attributes of each PAI design and presenting the traffic operational analysis and land-use activity/density analysis to demonstrate how alternative intersection designs can make it possible to both manage traffic and catalyze great mixed-use developments.

Additionally, this project conducted two focus groups to obtain information about stakeholders’ perceptions, attitudes, and knowledge about placemaking strategies and their assessment on how proposed intersection strategies and visual models developed may address needs and preferences in the selected partnering communities, particularly addressing growth and potential development of mixed-use development opportunities. Focus groups involved experts with varying backgrounds, including bike/pedestrian advocates, real estate appraisers, mixed-use developers, real estate market analysists, planners, transit planners and engineers, academicians in urban design, economists, land use and city planners, state level DOT staff, and local government representatives. In general, focus group participants agreed that our project is innovative and the proposed PAI design strategies are potentially revolutionary benefiting communities. They provided consensus about the rapid growth in suburban communities, but yet the existing commercial roadways and the outdated retail development require newer approaches. They agree that the current and future preferences in terms of housing for various age-groups; changing nature of retail experiences; the types of commercial areas; parking requirements; people's preferences on mobility and the provision of multi-modal transportation opportunities and street infrastructure should all support the creation of walkable, sustainable, and equitable mixed-use activity centers  that will be safe, accessible, and livable. They also provided their assessment of the perceived performance of PAIs offering foundation for placemaking in terms of block size, accessibility, connectivity, local street character, alternative mode features, parking policies and regulations, form-based zoning, stakeholder interests, and real estate market trends. These are improtant factors to consider when determining whether a location is a good candidate for PAI and place-making investment strategies. However, focus groups revealed that the proposed innovative strategies can be disruptive and perceived as threatening by many, if they are not executed without complete buy-in from the broader community. They provided advice to present incremental change with alternative options and deliver a thorough market analysis of pros and cons, including short and long-term return value. Devising a community engagement plan to convert losers into winners, or at least minimize their fears is a priority. The future steps of this effort will aim to do that. 


Last Modified: 07/30/2023
Modified by: Celen Pasalar
